quiz.title: Unit 6: Market Structures (Quiz 2)
quiz.subtitle: 6.2 Perfect Competition: Ideal Competitive Markets (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Perfect Competition Characteristics, Profit Maximization, Short-run and Long-run Equilibrium

questions.question: In perfect competition, individual firms are described as:
questions.explanation: Firms in perfect competition are price takers because each firm is so small relative to the market that it cannot influence the market price and must accept the price determined by market supply and demand.

questions.question: The demand curve faced by an individual perfectly competitive firm is:
questions.explanation: Each firm faces a perfectly elastic (horizontal) demand curve at the market price because it can sell any quantity at that price but would sell nothing if it tried to charge a higher price.

questions.question: For a perfectly competitive firm, marginal revenue equals:
questions.explanation: Since the firm can sell all output at the market price, each additional unit sold adds exactly the price to total revenue, so $MR = P$.

questions.question: A perfectly competitive firm maximizes profit by producing where:
questions.explanation: Like all profit-maximizing firms, perfect competitors produce where marginal revenue equals marginal cost. Since $MR = P$ in perfect competition, this is equivalent to $P = MC$.

questions.question: In the short run, a perfectly competitive firm will shut down if:
questions.explanation: If price falls below average variable cost, the firm cannot cover its variable costs and should shut down immediately to minimize losses (fixed costs are sunk in the short run).

questions.question: The short-run supply curve for a perfectly competitive firm is:
questions.explanation: The firm will only produce if $P \geq AVC$, so its supply curve is the portion of the $MC$ curve that lies above the minimum point of the $AVC$ curve.

questions.question: In long-run competitive equilibrium, firms earn:
questions.explanation: Free entry and exit ensure that in long-run equilibrium, firms earn zero economic profit (normal profit only), where $P = ATC$ at the minimum point.

questions.question: In long-run competitive equilibrium, firms produce at:
options: The minimum point of the $ATC$ curve
The profit-maximizing point regardless of cost
questions.explanation: Competitive pressure forces firms to produce at the minimum point of their average total cost curve, achieving productive efficiency.

questions.question: If firms in a perfectly competitive market are earning economic profits, in the long run:
options: New firms will enter the industry
questions.explanation: Economic profits attract new firms to enter the industry, increasing market supply and driving down the market price until economic profits are eliminated.

questions.question: Allocative efficiency occurs in perfect competition because:
questions.explanation: Allocative efficiency means resources are allocated to produce the goods and services most valued by society. This occurs when $P = MC$, which happens in long-run competitive equilibrium.

questions.question: For a perfectly competitive firm, if $P > ATC$ at the profit-maximizing output:
options: The firm is earning economic profits
questions.explanation: When price exceeds average total cost, the firm is earning economic profits because total revenue exceeds total cost.

questions.question: The break-even point for a perfectly competitive firm occurs where:
questions.explanation: The break-even point is where the firm earns zero economic profit, which occurs when price equals average total cost.

questions.question: If market demand increases in a perfectly competitive industry, in the short run:
options: Price will decrease and output will increase
Price will increase and firms will increase output
Firms will continue producing the same output
questions.explanation: Increased demand shifts the market demand curve rightward, increasing market price. Existing firms respond by moving up their $MC$ curves to produce more output where $P = MC$.

questions.question: In perfect competition, the market supply curve in the short run is:
options: The horizontal sum of individual firms' $MC$ curves
The vertical sum of individual firms' $ATC$ curves
questions.explanation: The short-run market supply curve is the horizontal summation of all individual firms' supply curves (the portions of their $MC$ curves above $AVC$).

questions.question: A constant-cost industry is one where:
options: Input prices increase as industry output expands
Input prices decrease as industry output expands
Input prices remain constant as industry output expands
questions.explanation: In a constant-cost industry, expansion doesn't affect input prices, so firms' cost curves remain unchanged, and the long-run supply curve is horizontal.

questions.question: The long-run industry supply curve in perfect competition is typically:
options: More elastic than the short-run supply curve
Less elastic than the short-run supply curve
The same as the short-run supply curve
questions.explanation: The long-run supply curve is more elastic because firms can enter or exit and adjust all inputs, making quantity supplied more responsive to price changes.

questions.question: If a perfectly competitive firm is producing where $P = MC$ but $P < ATC$, the firm should:
options: Continue operating in the short run if $P > AVC$
questions.explanation: Even though the firm is incurring losses ($P < ATC$), it should continue operating in the short run as long as $P > AVC$, because it can cover variable costs and contribute to fixed costs.

questions.question: Productive efficiency in perfect competition means:
options: Goods are produced at minimum cost
The right mix of goods is produced
questions.explanation: Productive efficiency occurs when goods are produced at the lowest possible cost, which happens in long-run competitive equilibrium where firms produce at the minimum point of the $ATC$ curve.

questions.question: For a perfectly competitive firm, if $MR > MC$ at the current output level, the firm should:
questions.explanation: When marginal revenue exceeds marginal cost, producing an additional unit adds more to revenue than to cost, so increasing production will increase profit.

questions.question: The key characteristic that makes perfect competition 'perfect' is:
questions.explanation: Perfect competition requires all these conditions: many small firms, identical products, perfect information, free entry and exit, and perfect resource mobility.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand perfect competition, including short-run and long-run equilibrium conditions and efficiency properties.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but review the profit-maximization rule, shutdown decision, and long-run adjustment process.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: the price taker concept, $MR = MC$ rule, short-run supply curve, and long-run equilibrium conditions.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that perfect competitors are price takers who maximize profit where $MR = MC$, and free entry/exit leads to zero economic profit in the long run.
